title: Nifty: Sliding May Be Too Steeper Amid Growing Meltdown Fever
text:
On analysis of the movements of , in different time frames, I find that the prevalence of growing global economic slowdown fear looks evident enough since the announcement of weak PMI data, which shows U.S. manufacturing activity index in September hit its lowest level in more than a decade, ISM data showed on Tuesday; looks evident enough to show the growing damaging impact of Sino-U.S. tariff trade tussle. On the other hand, weakening conditions in Europe and the slowdown in China, it's all adding up to the same thing essentially: worries that the global economy is slowing and giving investors reason to run for safety.

Although U.S. Federal Reserve, which cut interest rates for the second time this year in September, has indicated it would rely on economic data to determine future rate cuts, the central bank may reduce borrowing costs in October during its upcoming meeting at the end of this month. On the other hand, weak private payroll U.S. growth has also joined as another slower pace of growth in the U.S. Secondly, the steep fall in Indian equity markets on October 1st, 2019, as ; which may continue to extend exhaustion from October 3rd, 2019. I find that the currently prevailing sliding moves in U.S. and European equity markets may result in a gap-down opening in and on October 3rd, 2019; which may likely enforce both the Indian equity indices to break the lowest levels what they tested on October 1st, 2019.

Finally, I conclude that if the and start the trading session on October 3rd, with a gap-down and are not able to defend their respective lows of October 1st, 2019; sliding moves may be too steeper amid growing fear of global economic slowdown. No doubt that the quantum of volatility may be on the higher scale of October due to weekly expiry, but the overall trend continues to remain bearish in the absence of any positive news.
